explanation:
For checking MISRA C rule about use of <string.h> functions and out-of-bounds accesses you must inspect every place a string.h routine might be invoked and verify the buffer/length arguments. The following symbols are required and why:

- memset
  - parse_dauth_params calls memset(&userhash,0,sizeof(userhash)) and memset(&algorithm,0,sizeof(algorithm)). To ensure these calls do not write past object bounds you need the actual memset declaration/semantics (standard) and to confirm the sizeof operands match the real object sizes.

- struct MHD_RqDAuthParam
  - sizeof(userhash) and sizeof(algorithm) depend on this type. You must know its real layout and size to verify the memset length is correct. Also parse_dauth_params writes into userhash.value.str/len and param->quoted; understanding the contained fields is necessary to reason about any later string comparisons that may use those fields.

- struct MHD_RqDAuth
  - pdauth is a pointer to this type; parse_dauth_params assigns into pdauth->userhash, pdauth->qop, pdauth->algo3 and fills pointers to pdauth members into params[]. Knowing this structure is required to ensure no indirect writes/read (from memset or other calls) exceed member bounds and to check that members used as arguments to other functions are valid.

- struct _MHD_cstr_w_len and _MHD_S_STR_W_LEN (macro)
  - tk_names entries use _MHD_cstr_w_len->len and ->str. To verify index and length arithmetic (tk_name->len <= left, comparisons against str + i, and checks like tk_name->len == left) you need the definition/values, so you can ensure the code does not compare or pass lengths that permit out-of-bounds memory accesses when calling string comparison helpers.

- MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_, MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n, MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_
  - These functions are called from parse_dauth_params to compare token names and the userhash value with literal "true". They are likely to perform bounded memory reads or call standard string.h routines (memcmp/strlen/strncmp). To determine whether any string.h call inside parse_dauth_params (directly or indirectly) can read past buffer bounds you must inspect the implementations or at least their contracts (do they accept length-limited buffers and avoid NUL-terminated assumptions?).

- get_rq_dauth_algo and get_rq_dauth_qop
  - They are called at the end of parse_dauth_params with pointers to local 'algorithm' and pdauth->qop_raw. Their implementations may call standard string.h functions (memcmp, strlen, etc.) on the value buffers filled earlier. To ensure no out-of-bounds accesses result from the data parsed here you must inspect these callees.

- memcmp and strlen
  - These are the common string.h primitives that the MHD_str_equal_* helpers or the get_rq_dauth_* functions might use. To conclude whether any string.h calls access beyond buffer bounds you either need the implementations of the higher-level helpers or, at minimum, to consider how memcmp/strlen would be invoked (what pointers and lengths would be supplied). Including memcmp and strlen ensures the analysis examines the standard-library calls that could produce violations.

In short: you must have the types and macros that determine sizes/lengths and the implementations (or precise contracts) of the helper comparison functions and the callees get_rq_dauth_* to trace any indirect calls into <string.h> (memcmp/strlen/etc.) and confirm all pointer/length arguments are within the referenced object bounds.
